com.google.android.agera

Class Reservoirs

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.google.android.agera.Reservoirs

  • public final class Reservoirs
extends java.lang.Object
    Utility methods for creating Reservoir instances.

    Any Reservoir created by this class has to be created from a Looper thread or the method will throw an IllegalStateException.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Concrete Methods

    • Method Detail

      • reservoirOf

        public static <T> Reservoir<T> reservoirOf(java.lang.Class<T> clazz)
        Returns a Reservoir for the given value type.

        The returned reservoir uses a standard unbounded FIFO queue as its backing storage. As a result, all values are accepted and no duplication checks are used, and they are dequeued in the same order.

      • reservoir

        public static <T> Reservoir<T> reservoir()
        Same as reservoirOf(Class). This variant is useful for when the value type is more readily inferrable from the context, such as when used as a variable initializer or a return value, so client code could simply write, for example, 
         Reservoir<String> stringReservoir = reservoir();
        where this method is statically imported. This also helps in-line creation of a reservoir whose value type is generic, such as List<String>, so client code could write Reservoirs.<List<String>>reservoir() instead of the less readable reservoirOf((Class<List<String>>) null).

      • reservoir

        public static <T> Reservoir<T> reservoir(java.util.Queue<T> queue)
        Returns a Reservoir that uses the given queue as the backing storage for enqueuing and dequeuing values. It is up to the concrete Queue.offer(E) implementation of the queue instance whether and how to accept each value to be enqueued.
        Parameters:
        queue - The backing storage of the reservoir. Any valid Queue implementation can be used, including non-FIFO queues such as PriorityQueue. Only these methods are used: Queue.offer(E) for attempting to enqueue a value, Queue.poll() for attempting to dequeue a value, and Collection.isEmpty() for state check. All accesses are synchronized on this queue instance; if the queue must also be accessed elsewhere, those accesses must also be synchronized on this queue instance. Also note that modifications to the queue outside the Reservoir interface will not update the reservoir or its registered Updatables.
